title.narrative: FGG SOMO ToC 1: Improved Corporate Conduct

description.narrative: The first long-term goal of the Fair, Green and Global Alliance is to ensure that corporate conduct advances social justice, decent work and environmental sustainability. SOMO together with the other FGG Alliance members believe that corporations, including private banks, have a role in and responsibility for fighting poverty and injustice and promoting inclusive and sustainable development. This requires a fundamental change in corporate conduct, including changes to basic decisions about investment, buying practices and sourcing. SOMO contributes to this goal through strategies on government regulation and standards, corporate policies and practices, and supporting HRDs and ensuring effective remedy. Activities include doing research, capacity building, advocacy, organizing public events, facilitate the exchange of information, filing complaints at judicial or non-judicial complaint mechanisms, and contributing to the activities of the other FGG members. The work in this program is organized in dossiers to enable cooperation between alliance members. The specific activities of SOMO are described below. In the dossier Crosscutting corporate regulation and accountability, SOMO will continue empowering partners to actively advocate on the UN Binding Treaty process at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHCR) in order to advance a new regulatory framework providing effective access to remedy and justice for corporate human rights violations in communities. SOMO will advocate for an encompassing scope of and an effective grievance mechanism in the UN Treaty. SOMO will furthermore work to further specify the OECD guidelines in particular sectors in the context of OECD Watch. In the dossier Sector and issue specific government interventions to regulate corporate conduct, SOMO will contribute to the work of the FGG Alliance on several topics. On the topic of land and natural resources governance, SOMO will continue to do research and capacity building on land related conflicts between companies and affected communities. Central in this work has been promoting Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) in government and company policy. On the topic of Corporate conduct and labor migration, SOMO will research the human rights responsibility of corporate end users of migrant labor. The focus in case studies and legal analyses will be the recruitment practices and adherence to internationally recognized labor rights of labor intermediaries and subcontractors. SOMO will also engage in capacity building for CSOs working on migrant labor, through the dissemination of the SOMO-LSI Toolkit. On the topic of Increased cooperation on lobbying transparency and regulation, SOMO develops a proposal to increase lobby transparency and regulation. The accompanying activities will contribute to government regulation and standards in an open and democratic setting by countering corporate power. In the dossier Sector and issue specific government interventions to regulate corporate conduct, SOMO's activities will mainly focus on the following sectors: extractives and pharmaceuticals. SOMO in cooperation with her partners wants to build up evidence showing how much drug development costs are actually paid by tax money thus supporting lobby towards governments to demand that pharmaceutical companies reveal the cost structure behind the excessive high medicine prices. SOMO will additionally lobby EU-authorities to improve the monitoring of clinical trials in the Global South and develop capacities of partners to support claims of vulnerable clinical trial participants, defend their rights, and address corporate misconduct. SOMO further wants to cooperate with the University of Utrecht and Open Source Publishing movement to challenge the business model of pharmaceutical companies and to propose actions to the government. In the dossier Improved corporate conduct in consumer goods — labour rights, SOMO will exert influence on companies to improve their business conduct so workers and communities’ rights are protected and respected, and grievances are effectively remediated. SOMO and its partners present in garment and electronics production countries will be involved in new case studies and evaluations. The international networks such as GoodElectronics, and Electronics Watch are involved in research, exchange of information, lobby, campaigning and capacity building. SOMO plans to file complaints at judicial or non-judicial complaint mechanisms based on case studies in the supply chain of consumer goods. Additionally, SOMO will share lessons learned with public sector buyers to improve corporate conduct based on case studies of workers’ rights violations and evaluations of voluntary initiatives and the first (enforceable) brand agreements. SOMO will continue to collect a body of evidence to demonstrate the weaknesses of corporate self-regulation and self-auditing, and the necessary shift towards more worker led-monitoring. In the dossier Improved corporate conduct of companies and banks/investors in sectors related to natural resources use and environmental rights, SOMO's Corporate Research Knowledge Center will develop and increase research capacity of partners. It will develop new research methods and incorporate existing methods from other research disciplines, and maintain and update SOMO’s research manual accordingly. SOMO will explore together with Both ENDS how to develop the normative legal case for divestment from fossil fuel related companies including exploring the use of OECD Guidelines as well as using multi-stakeholder processes to influence pension funds and institutional investors in the fossil fuel supply chain. In the dossier Enabling environment for civil society and human rights defenders, SOMO will work with partners on a project aimed at supporting human rights defenders and their organizations in defending human rights by using non-judicial grievance mechanisms. Additionally, SOMO’s Multinationals in Conflict-Affected Areas (MCAA) program will continue researching the impacts on human rights of MNCs operating in conflict-affected areas. These MNCs work in a context that is characterized by increased political tension, social instability, a fragile infrastructure, and a heightened risk of new outbreaks of violence. The presence of MNCs in these areas is associated with elevated human rights risks, and there are real risks of MNCs operating at the detriment of local communities and the environment. The ultimate aim of the program is to prevent MNCs to contribute to conflict and human rights abuses in conflict-affected areas by increasing accountability and empowering civil society. In the dossier Access to effective remedy for victims of business-related human rights and environmental abuse, SOMO and its partners involved in various grievance mechanisms will continue supporting workers, communities, individuals and CSOs in the Global South seeking to address and prevent human rights abuses related to corporate activity. In providing support to complainants, SOMO will partner with national and regional CSOs — such as OECD Watch members, in order to transfer knowledge.

A range of alternative, participatory initiatives and models related to corporate conduct have been developed, piloted and promoted by FGG and civil society actors, from best practices through to enforceable multi-stakeholder agreements.

comment.narrative: (1) In 2020 the working group of NGOs and union members of the MVO Platform, responsible for the management of the project, was further extended with new members (International Justice Mission in the overall working group, the Salvation Army and Tony’s Chocolonely’s in the campaign group). In September, the MVO Platform (hosted by SOMO) launched the Initiative for Sustainable and Responsible Business Conduct (IDVO) (www.IDVO.org). First members of this initiative were, besides members of the MVO Platform, 49 companies that also already signed a letter initiated by Tony Chocolonely’s in June to Minister Kaag of Foreign Trade and Development. This letter was also drafted in close consultation with the working group. In December IDVO consisted of 61 companies, 36 NGOs, 2 trade unions, 10 scientists and 1 church. Companies joining the initiative come from different sectors (such as food, garment, electronics, consultancy, finance/ banking and recycling) and range from multinational and large enterprises (like IKEA, Wessanen (Food company), Nestlé, ASN Bank, Zeeman, Suit Supply), and small(er) social enterprises (like Dopper, Waka Waka, Moyu) to business networks (like MVO Nederland).

As described in the plan for 2018, SOMO intended to influence 3 alternative proposals for alternative, participatory initiatives and models related to corporate conduct. As indicator 1.C counts actual alternatives rather than measures or developments that influence an alternative we decided to report our achieved results under 1.D.

In 2017, 3 participatory initiatives on worker driven monitoring together with local partners were developed. (1) An initiative on worker driven monitoring to support electronic workers to be in the driver seat in developing and implementing the monitoring of labour conditions at factory level was developed. (2) A model for socially responsible public procurement of ICT hardware involving local monitors as an alternative model for current procurement practices was developed. (3) Lastly, SOMO provided substantial inputs for methodology and procedures for a proposal for a database of all business enterprises involved in certain specified activities concerning settlements that may negatively affect human rights. Generally, SOMO sat in as a Board of Trustees in the electronics sustainability sector. SOMO has been in touch with and has given support/advice/contacts/input to sector-representative in the Netherlands. And lastly, SOMO uses its input and influence along with its good relationships with other NGOs to help the process and methodology to assist in the development of alternatives

In 2019 the MVO Platform working group, including partners in LLMICs, on mandatory Human Rights Due Diligence developed a proposal for a broad mandatory Human Rights Due Diligence law in the Netherlands with financial and technical support from SOMO, building on and improving the Child Labour Due Diligence law that was adopted in May 2019 in an attempt to ensure that business-related human rights abuses in LLMICs are better prevented and remedied.

"2 alternative, participatory initiatives related to corporate conduct meeting core criteria including sustainability, participation (m/f), transparency and equity (m/f) have been developed with CSOs in LLMICs. These include 1) a worker-led monitoring initiative developed by a Mexican CSO in collaboration with other CSOs in the Electronics Watch network (supported by SOMO) for electronics factories that puts workers at the centre of the monitoring and compliance process, which was developed based on a survey, interviews and a webinar involving 35 experts of different monitoring organisations and social audit firms. webinar on worker driven monitoring methodology; 2) a worker-oriented participatory approach to factory monitoring in the Myanmar garment industry. SOMO and two Myanmar CSOs contributed to the result by training a team of (ex) garment factory workers to conduct research into labour rights issues in the Myanmar garment industry. The (ex) factory workers used their first-hand experience and contacts with factory workers to ensure that current factory workers were involved and committed to the research and the local CSOs after the initial research phase. 3) Within the LobbyWatch network, SOMO initiated and coordinated the Lobbywatch NL position paper which proposes a set of policy recommendations to regulate lobbying, which was published on December 14th. description.narrative: Both the rights and the legal and political spaces needed to claim and defend those rights are protected for people, communities and civil society actors, enabling them to address misconduct and grievances successfully, and promote improved corporate conduct and related governmental regulation.

# effective legal and other grievance mechanisms adopted or improved by governments and corporations via which CSOs and communities can resolve grievances with governments and companies, and claim their environmental, human and worker rights.

comment.narrative:
*(1) Following OECD Watch's first-ever complaint against an NCP to the OECD Investment Committee, in November 2018 the Australian Treasury Department made concrete improvements to the Australian NCP's complaint handling procedures to make the NCP more accessible, predictable, and equitable. This is a concrete improvement in a government complaints-handling body. The mechanism is now more accessible and equitable for CSOs in LLMICs seeking remedy for abuse by Australian corporations. SOMO, as secretariat of OECD Watch, coordinated with the network and specifically Australian members to develop and file the complaint that led to the change in Australian government policy.
*(2) Through advocacy of SOMO through the OECD Watch network, and direct consultation by one of OECD Watch's partners, the Czech NCP revised several provisions of its rules of procedure to simplify the steps to filing, establish conflict of interest rules, define tasks between the NCP and its secretariat, allow the Secretariat to engage an external mediator, and set new rules for confidentiality protecting the right of parties to speak more freely about their cases in future (1).Through advocacy of SOMO through the OECD Watch network, and direct consultation by one of OECD Watch's partners, the Polish NCP also revised its rules of procedure to promote transparency in its complaint filing processes(1).This outcome will ease the process for NGOs and other stakeholders using the Czech and Polish NCPs to file complaints to these two NCPs. This will make it easier for complainants from LLMICs negatively impacted by Czech and Polish companies' operations to file complaints. SOMO hosts the OECD Watch network.

Two grievance mechanisms – the German and Danish National Contact Point (NCP) mechanism of the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises – were improved to better enable CSOs and communities to resolve grievances with companies and claim their environmental, human and worker rights. In December 2016, Germany announced in its National Action Plan (NAP) on Business and Human Rights that it would restructure and improve its National Contact Point. OECD Watch participated in stakeholder meetings to provide recommendations on Germany’s NAP. In June 2016 the Danish NCP improved its procedures for handling cases. OECD Watch contributed to the result by providing input on the functioning of the Danish NCP during the NCP’s peer review process in 2015. OECD Watch was one of the official stakeholders. SOMO contributed to this result via the OECD Watch network, which it supports and hosts.

Plan 2019 *In 2019, 2 governments in North Africa and/or Middle East establish a National Contact Point as a result of OECDWatch advocacy that is financially support by SOMO, which also hosts the network.

description.narrative: # mechanisms put in place or improved by governments that guarantee access for civil society to democratic decision making processes related to corporate conduct, including the right to resist developments.

comment.narrative: In 2017, SOMO and its local partner created 3 mechanisms for lobbying transparency. The lobbying transparency was put in place by the Dutch government in order to guarantee access for civil society for democratic decision making processes related to corporate conduct, including the right to resist developments. Specifically, the first mechanism referred to regulating revolving door practices. This policy is in line with key recommendations that SOMO and its Lobbywatch NL coalition partners have pushed for in recent years. The second mechanism was about recognizing and ensuring a legislative footprint, this ensures the government includes information on the influence of lobbyists in legislation. This creates more transparency on the influence of corporations on policy and enables CSOs to challenge corporate capture. The final mechanism referred to partner’s research and influencing contributed to political debate and policy change concerning lobbying transparency. The Dutch Parliament held a debate at the end of January 2017 about lobbying in the Netherlands and potential measures to regulate it.

Through making formal submissions giving feedback on its favoured candidates for the critical position of Chair of the OECD Working Party on Responsible Business Conduct, OECD Watch helped influence the selection of a new Chair (Christine Kaufmann) who is favourable towards civil society interests in both the general improvement of NCPs and the promotion of access to remedy through NCPs, also including through the anticipated revision of the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises.. In January 2019 she officially began her term and she will stay for 7 years. SOMO supported this outcome by hosting the OECD Watch secretariat.

3 mechanisms regarding lobby transparency, the textiles and garment industry, and mining and electronics sector are put in place or improved by governments that guarantee access for civil society to democratic decision making processes related to corporate conduct, including the right to resist developments.

description.narrative: Improved corporate policies and government regulations have been put into practice and enforced.
# concrete steps taken by companies to actively identify, prevent and mitigate adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of their activities and those in their value chains.

comment.narrative: (1)In May 2019, Dutch textile company Zeeman for the first time published a list with its production locations. This enables workers in Zeeman's supply chain in LLMICs to call upon Zeeman to take accountability for human rights or labour rights violations when they occur in their supplier factories. It also enables civil society actors to independently verify claims made by Zeeman. (1)Following pressure and dialogues with GoodElectronics (GE) and its members (ICRT, CEREAL and others) Apple has continued to verify the process chemicals at their final assembly facilities. GE is pushing the company to go deep down the supply chain. In 2018, Apple added n-Propyl Bromide (nPB) to the list of banned chemicals for cleaning and degreasing. GE is hosted by SOMO. (1)Through supporting civil society and community complainants from France, Ghana, and Nigeria, OECD Watch helped support an agreement via the Italian National Contact Point between the NGOs and Italian company ENI, whereby ENI agreed to correct years of serious flooding resulting from its business activity that had made a community in Nigeria almost unlivable for over four decades. The agreement is significant because it represents a major tangible win for an LLMIC community that had faced egregious health, economic, and social impacts from ENI, and because it represents an important practice shift by a major multinational enterprise. SOMO supported this outcome by hosting the OECD Watch network.

(3) Following the filing of the particulars of the claim against Camellia (parent of a large agricultural company) in the UK, in October 2020, SOMO and partners sustained media/communications efforts which led to considerable exposure of the case and subsequent pressure on Camellia and its daughter company. Three large UK supermarkets, Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Lidl, announced they stopped purchasing avocados from the agricultural company over the human rights violations at the core of the lawsuit.
(1) OECD Watch supported the Australian NCP by providing examples of how companies have provided compensation to victims of impacts, and encouraged the Australian NCP to enable dialogue between ANZ Bank and complainants Inclusive Development International and Equitable Cambodia about compensation. Dialogue occurred and helped the parties reach an agreement whereby ANZ Bank paid compensation to communities adversely impacted by a Cambodian sugar production project funded by ANZ.
(1) In January 2021, three pharmaceutical companies eventually made their contracts for COVID-19 vaccines available for Members of the European Parliament after strong pressure on the European Commission (EC) to push for this transparency. A group of 39 civil society organisations, including SOMO, urged the European Commission and EU national governments to ensure a maximum degree of transparency in the EU’s deals with pharmaceutical companies over COVID19 vaccines. The three companies include Curevac, BioNTech and Pfizer, and AstraZeneca. Transparency is both crucial to guarantee accountability and scrutiny and for ensuring confidence in vaccines.

*(1) In July 2018, Rainforest Alliance has withdrawn the certification of an agricultural company based in East Africa after the certification body has found irregularities in and around the company's plantations after a re-certification audit of the company's avocado production in the Makuyu area. Problems associated with the company's operations include: land rights issues, land evictions, blocked access to roads and public services, violence by the company's guards, labour rights abuses, sexual harassment, intimidation of human rights defenders, and environmental and wildlife concerns. Although these problems have not been addressed and the withdrawal offers no direct remedy for affected workers and community members, it is a recognition that the company's operations are not in compliance with the Rainforest Alliance standards and might have an indirect effect on the company's performance. Following SOMO’s field visit to the impacted communities in June 2017, SOMO has contacted Rainforest Alliance to informally alert them about the situation on the ground, because one of the company's avocado farms in the area was Rainforest Alliance certified. Although no official complaint has been filed by either SOMO or its partners, Rainforest Alliance responded quickly, and after several conversations between SOMO, one of SOMO's partners, Rainforest Alliance headquarters and the Nairobi office, an additional audit and a re-certification audit have taken place.
*(1) Business association Modint formulated a short brief for its members with regard to human rights and labour rights risks that come with sourcing from garment factories in Myanmar. Modint is one of the three big business associations for the garment and textiles industry in the Netherlands, with hundreds of company members. With this brief, Modint responds to concerns with regard to human and labour rights in the Myanmar garment industry as outlined in SOMO's “The Myanmar Dilemma”(2017), and update August 2017, and the presentations given by SOMO and its partner organisations in February 2018 at the Modint office for Dutch garment companies. Modint has asked and obtained SOMO's input for this brief. One of SOMO's partner organisations provides input on an ongoing basis, which helps SOMO be up-to-date about issues in the garment industry. The lion share of the labour force in the Myanmar’s’ garment industry is made up by women.
*(1) Suitsupply presented a roadmap towards freedom of association in Myanmar during the workshop on labour issues in the Myanmar garment industry on 21 February 2018 (organised by SOMO, Dutch business associations and CKT). During the presentation, Suitsupply acknowledged the role of SOMO in raising the issue and in facilitating contact with local stakeholders. Suitsupply spoke positively about the cooperation with a local partner and said they would continue to work with them in the process of creating an enabling environment for the workers to set up an independent and democratic factory-level trade union. Noticeably, the work here indicates direct and concrete collaboration between a garment brand and a local labour rights group. Commitment by a garment brand (Suitsupply) to work on FoA in a supplier factory. The contact between Suitsupply and our local partner is a direct result of the research SOMO did with them (and another organisation) for The Myanmar Dilemma and the joint follow-up activities to disseminate that report, including the discussion session at Modint with Dutch garment companies in Feb. 2018 where SOMO had asked Suitsupply to present on its supplier policy. It was in this context that Suit Supply made the commitment to work towards FoA.
*(1) German online garment retailer Otto Group urged its supplier in Myanmar - Running Tex - to address labour rights abuses, after being pressured by one of SOMO's partner organisations, CCC, SOMO and Femnet. The main problem at hand was the unlawful dismissal of a union leader at one of Otto’s supplier factories in Myanmar, as well as other ongoing labour rights violations at the supplier. After face-to-face discussions with one of SOMO's partner organisations, a trade union and SOMO in February 2018, Otto agreed to send a letter to the factory management. On 5 March 2018, the Otto Group sent a letter, describing a number of unresolved labour rights issues and urging the factory to respect the decision of the Arbitration Council to reinstate the dismissed union leader and urging the factory to engage with the factory trade union. Otto agreed to meet face to face and listen to concerns voiced by Myanmar labour rights groups, SOMO and Femnet and subsequently took concrete action towards its Myanmar supplier to resolve unresolved labour issues at the factory. SOMO, together with Femnet, put pressure on the Otto Group to meet with one of SOMO's partner organisations. SOMO, the partner organisation, Femnet and CCC jointly prepared the meeting. The meeting in fact was a follow-up to The Myanmar Dilemma report. The different organisations involved all played their role: SOMO's partner organisation is supporting the dismissed union leader and the other workers at Running Tex and collects evidence on the labour rights issues at Running Tex. CCC supports the partner organisation. All organisations jointly prepared for the meeting. SOMO and Femnet engaged with the Otto Group to set up the meeting. The meeting was attended by SOMO's partner organisation, SOMO and Femnet.
*(4) On July 2018, Samsung Electronics agreed to a binding arbitration framework with 4 concrete steps with Good Electronics member Sharps in South Korea. Samsung agreed to: i) put in place safety measures proposed by the mediation committee by October 2018; ii) make a formal apology to victims, iii) compensate SHARPS-profiled victims; iv) compensate new victims for the next ten years. On November 23 2018, Samsung apologized to victims for the deaths and illnesses caused by its unsafe working conditions. Under the compensation program, the company will distribute up to KRW 150 million (U$132,667) for the illnesses and deaths of former and current workers. SOMO and GoodElectronics have constantly supported SHARPS during their 1,023 day sit-in and campaign in South Korea. SOMO/GoodElectronics has repeatedly sent letters and held meetings with Samsung executives voicing out SHARPS’s concerns and demands. During the last meeting held between SOMO/GE and Samsung Europe on August 24 in Brussels SOMO stressed that the global civil society network is monitoring closely the implementation of the arbitration agreement by Samsung and provided recommendations for the security measures that need to be implemented. Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd has agreed to a binding arbitration framework that will likely compel one of the world’s most powerful corporation to fully compensate and earnestly apologize to victims of its occupational-disease clusters. According to Sharps: “It was likely the beginning of an end to an era, at least in South Korea and it was a first of its kind moment in the country’s labor history”.
*(1) In July 2018 Norges Bank (the central bank of Norway) announced its decision to exclude four companies from the Government Pension Fund Global, follow one company through active ownership and place three companies under observation. Among these are the textile and garment manufacturers Luthai Textile Co Ltd, which featured in SOMO’s report the Myanmar Dilemma (the majority of garment workers in Myanmar are women). After the publication, SOMO was contacted by the Council of Ethics of the Norwegian Government Pension Fund which led to 1 concrete step to start its own investigation into Luthai. SOMO’s research findings led the Council of Ethics to decide to do this investigation and when its own investigation confirmed SOMO’s findings, it led to the decision to advise the Norges bank to exclude the company. Institutional investors have considerable leverage over the companies they invest in. The Council on Ethics recommended to exclude the company Luthai Textile Co Ltd from the Government Pension Fund due to an unacceptable risk of the company being responsible for systematic human rights violations. Luthai owns textiles and garment manufacturing facilities in a number of countries. The recommendation is based on investigations into working conditions which uncovered systematic norm violation at the company’s factories in Cambodia and Myanmar, including the use of young people below the age of 18 under the same terms as adults, numerous occupational health and safety hazards and restrictions on freedom of association. The Council on Ethics gives weight to the fact that, previously, Luthai seems only to a limited extent to have implemented measures resulting in lasting improvements in working conditions. Combined with the fact that Luthai is unwilling to provide insights into how it runs its business operations, this leads the Council to conclude that there is an unacceptable risk of Luthai being responsible for systematic human rights violations in the future, too.
*(1) In December 2018, Fair Wear Foundation (FWF) published an amended list with factories in Myanmar Supplying FWF Members. In line with the recommendations put forward by SOMO together with CCC and based on consultation with three Myanmar partners, the list now includes additional information such as ownership, whether there is a democratically elected trade union active at the factory. In addition, the list includes information about former supplier factories and the reasons why FWF member stopped sourcing there. The additional information now included in the FWF Myanmar supplier list enables local and international stakeholders to better monitor FWF and FWF members’ activities and effectiveness in Myanmar. In addition, by going a step further in providing supply chain transparency, FWF may stimulate other MSIs and companies to take further steps towards greater transparency. SOMO together with CCC and in consultation with local partners gave input for FWF’s Myanmar policy. SOMO presented its recommendations in a meeting of FWF’s Committee of Experts. After long deliberations, SOMO and CCC’s recommendations were accepted and processed in a new policy document (see outcome 24). The amended supplier list of December 2018 demonstrates that FWF has implemented the intended changes with regard to transparency about supplier factories.

3 concrete steps were taken by companies to actively identify, prevent and mitigate adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of their activities and those in their value chains. These include: 1) Steps taken by one of the most important gold refiners for the electronics industry, which has conducted an extensive due diligence process on their sourcing of gold from artisanal mining and adapted their sourcing practices and methodologies to source artisanal gold. SOMO contributed to the result with reports on artisinal gold mining and the Round Table on the Responsible Mining of Electronics in April, 2016; 2) Steps taken by a Swiss pharmaceutical company, which carried out a thorough due dillegence assessment on their on-going and completed clinical trials in Egypt. SOMO contributed to the result though a report and advocacy efforts in cooperation with Egyptian CSOs. 3) Steps taken by a garment factory in Myanmar which is now providing pay slips to its workers who previously lacked information about their wage structure and could not verify if they got paid what they were entitled to. SOMO contributed to the result by supporting a CSO in Myanmar to advocate on behalf of the workers.

In 2017, SOMO established 6 concrete steps have been taken by companies to mitigate adverse activities of their activities in their value chains. Through activities such as identification, prevention and mitigation of adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of companies’ activities and actors in their value chain together with local partners. Change of practice is significant particularly to the energy sector because they have new information, new power, and a new advocacy route to prevent and remedy human rights and environmental violations. Regarding the garment industry, SOMO met with Dutch garment brand on two occasions and urged the company to enter into direct dialogue with supplier factory featured in the report. SOMO attended and facilitated multiple meetings with companies and local partners in order to establish clear lines of communication, facilitation and engagement. In 201 7 a large steel company withdraws from large project. A large South Korean corporation, signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Government in eastern India, to build a steel plant, power station and port. The proposed project would have impacted 11 villages and nearly 4000 people. A campaign to stop the project was established and active for many years. As part of the campaign, OECD Watch worked on (within the FGG alliance) to file an NCP complaint concerning the steel company’s human rights and environmental breaches to the Guidelines. A concrete step has been taken by a company to fulfil its obligations in terms of a payment, following the conclusion of a complaint handled by the Dutch NCP. The specific instance complaint that was supported by OECD Watch. Lastly, in cooperation with a strategic partner, SOMO and BothENDS together mutually capacitated and redesigned a coal fired power plant to “replace the direct seawater cooling system with a cooling tower discharging into a cooling basin, in order to avoid marine impacts potentially arising from the thermal discharge.” These concrete steps generally improve the value chains of valuable sectors working both locally and abroad. SOMO engages all stakeholders to comply with the concrete steps and encourages companies continue to review their value chains.

description.narrative: # concrete steps taken by governments to actively identify, prevent and mitigate adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of corporate activities and those in corporations' value chains.

comment.narrative: (1) OECD Watch encouraged the Australian NCP to improve its practices around complaint acceptance, by successfully encouraging it to reverse a decision to reject a complaint about climate change because "climate change" is not specifically addressed in the Guidelines text. OECD Watch also encouraged the Australian NCP to open negotiation over whether a company could provide compensation to victims, even though NCPs do not officially have authority to mandate that remedial compensation be paid.

(2)OECD Watch supported the Dutch government in its request for and the Dutch NCP's issuance of a report (negatively) evaluating the Dutch oil and gas sector's compliance with the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. As a result the Dutch oil and gas sector (private sector) is now required to implement an action plan to bring itself into alignment with the OECD Guidelines (1), and the Dutch government is using its NCP proactively as a means through which to advance its own sustainability policy agenda (1). This represents two distinct changes in practice by the Dutch government to date, only one other government (the Danish) uses the NCP itself to conduct research on sustainability practices of a sector or ministry. (1)Following petitions filed by multiple Kakuzi impacted communities, the National Land Commission (NLC) of Kenya put out a formal notice in the legal Gazette of 1 March 2019 that the agricultural company Kakuzi should a) give access to public utilities on its property and b) that its land leases should not be renewed. SOMO financially supported the communities to file petitions to the NLC. (1)As a response to SOMOs report “Overpriced” and in the line with a commitment to discuss public funding of biomedical R&D, the Dutch Ministry of Health started to set up a research study about the 'eco-system of funding biomedical R&D'. SOMO and Wemos were invited by the civil servants who are in the lead to set up this research as they wanted some explanations about the report 'Overpriced'. The research objectives of the study cover the topics of improving Dutch public funding in biomedical R&D, and how the Dutch government can make a positive change.

A concrete step was taken by members of the EU Parliament to actively identify, prevent and mitigate adverse social, gender and environmental impacts of pharmaceutial company clinical trials in Egypt: a question has been submitted to the European Parliament and to the European Medicines Agency (EMA) about the checks the EMA is obliged to carry out according to the Clinical Trial Regulation and if they have checked and/or will check trials in Egypt. SOMO contributed to the result though a report and advocacy efforts in cooperation with Egyptian CSOs.

In 2017, concrete actions led by EU government, Dutch government and by public sector actors together with local partners in the Dutch sectors, 2 concrete steps have been taken by 3 governments in the north. More specifically, SOMO has been amongst the leading CSOs in Europe to advocate for European participation to develop a binding instrument on transnational corporations and other business enterprises with respect to human right. Advocacy efforts included: an online petition, social media messaging, and mobilization of parliamentarians in the Netherlands and Brussels. When public sector buyers in many countries take action together, based on the same supply chain intelligence and the same enforceable contract requirements, working conditions can improve. Another concrete step entails a national-level agency to join an electronic sector CSO. Public sector affiliated members require their contractors to exercise due diligence to achieve respect for labour rights and safety standards in factories that assemble or make the components of the goods they purchase. When the public sector buyers in many countries take action together, based on the same supply chain and the same enforceable contract requirements, working conditions can improve. These concrete steps were taken by the EU parliament to ensure companies promote more sustainable practices and are held accountable for respecting human rights.

Instead of getting a government actor to make an intervention related to the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and their responsibility for the ethics of clinical trials in LMMC’s, SOMO's activities led to 2 pharmaceutical companies, belonging to the largest pharmaceuticals worldwide have improved their policies on post-trial access to treatment (PTA) in 2018. This is reported under indicator 1.E.b
One of the cases researched by SOMO is corporate activity in the MENA region in violation of international law norms and the UNGPs. In 2018, SOMO continued to pursue its (Freedom of Information Act) FoIA request to the Dutch customs authorities, seeking information about Dutch import/export linking to the MENA region. Customs did not disclose any of that requested information, in a response to which SOMO filed a legal appeal. The court hearing for that appeal has been postponed (by the Amsterdam court) since November 2018. Furthermore, the law clinic of the University of Amsterdam, took up the legal analysis of corporate involvement in the MENA region, with the aim to feed into a potential legal claim in the Netherlands against a corporation involved in the MENA region. So far this has not resulted in a (worldwide) policy maker taking action against corporate complicity in state -sanctioned human rights violations, as we had initially planned.

2016-2017: 1 concrete step taken by 2 national and regional governments to actively improve practice to ascertain human standards regarding clinical trials.
2018: *In 2018, 1 government actor on national level in the Netherlands has made an intervention related to the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and their responsibility for the ethics of clinical trials in LMMC’s. *In 2018, 1 to be identified (worldwide) policymaker, takes action against corporate complicity in state -sanctioned human rights violations following and concerning SOMO and partners’ joint research findings. SOMO’s research will focus on the state-corporate crime angle.
2019: *In 2019 2 National Contact Points for the OECD Guidelines change their practice of handling of complaints filed by civil society organisations to ensure victims and organisations from LLMICs have better access to remedy after business-related human rights abuses, as a result of OECD Watch advocacy that is financially supported by SOMO, which also hosts the network.
2020: (2) In 2020, two National Contact Points (NCPs) for the OECD Guidelines change their practice of handling of complaints filed by civil society organisations to ensure victims and organisations from LLMICs have better access to remedy after business-related human rights abuses as a result of OECD Watch advocacy that is financially supported by SOMO, which also hosts the network.

description.narrative: Increased capacity of civil society actors to research, network and advocate in relation to the conduct of corporations.
# CSOs in LLMICs that lobby and advocate for responsible corporate conduct based on increased skills, knowledge or network contacts.

comment.narrative:
(0) Civil society was invited to comment in the OECD's process to review the Responsible Business Conduct (RBC) Policy Review of Peru. OECD Watch and a Peruvian partner CSO influenced the OECD's review as comments formulated by the CSO have been integrated into the RBC Policy Review.
(2) In 2020, various partners and CSOs in SOMO's network worldwide had better access to relevant data, tools and strategic analysis on companies, industries and markets, allowing them to more effectively further their work and reach their goals. The data that SOMO provided is information that is often not otherwise publicly or easily available and in many cases, it is not easy to understand or make sense of, which is why SOMO’s corporate research support has become increasingly important to many CSOs and partners. The data and analysis provided helps CSOs and partners "follow the money" and can reveal information about who holds the power to make decisions. In other cases, SOMO collects and analyses aggregated data, across different companies, sectors, or across regions in order to help answer CSOs’ and partners’ questions at the macro-level including on market influence, indebtedness, or shareholder influence, for example. With this information the CSOs and partners are better equipped to confront companies, their policies, their behavior, their executives, and their financiers directly, through shareholders, through the press or through legal or non-judicial means when they have better and more complete understanding of the companies. A selection of examples of how some CSOs use SOMO’s corporate research support for their research and lobby and advocacy follows:
A Central American organisation asked SOMO to help them provide corporate data, analysis and research support for a legal case focused on the financiers in a hydropower project in Central America.
Another organisation requested SOMO to help them provide data, investor information and analysis on a travel company that is profiting from advertising accommodation in occupied territories, for legal case against the company. This information is part of a broader project addressing several companies in the travel, holiday let, and vacation markets.
(1) To hold Rio Tinto accountable and inform its shareholders, a group of NGOs around the world working with front-line communities of Rio Tinto's mining activities, organised a joint letter and campaign during the AGM in April 2020. Since then the network has collectively supported the Australian campaign related to Juukan Gorge blast outrage as well as the prevention of the Arizona copper project. SOMO supports one of the CSOs involved here financially but also through research and generally as a strategic/sparring partner.
(0) One of SOMO's Indian partner CSOs has been coordinating with two other CSOs in India since 2018 to file a case of specific instance at the OECD National Contact Point in Japan. They have coordinated the complaint filing and have helped writing the first draft. SOMO/OECD Watch have read and commented on several drafts. On 22 December 2020, the two CSOs that SOMO's partnerorganisation was coordinating with filed a specific instance against Nitta Gelatin Inc. and Nitta Gelatin India Limited (NGIL) at the Japanese NCP(s).
(0) A Mexican CSO asked SOMO to provide information on financiers of wind and energy projects of Electricite du France (EDF) in France who potentially may be interested to finance a harmful wind project Gunaa Sicaru in Mexico. A project that is also led by EDF. The CSO used the information which exposed the EDF project portfolio to engage with the potential financier. As a result of this process, they discovered that the Gunaa Sicaru project financing was temporarily on hold and continue to monitor the financier's activities.
(1) During a three-day international event organised by Friends of the Earth Africa - the (1) African Peoples Tribunal on monoculture plantations in Nigeria - communities and civil society presented case studies on rights violations and environmental degradation connected with agro-commodities expansion in Africa. The case studies were partly informed by SOMO's corporate research. The cases were also reported in several regional media:Green Resources in Mozambique, Tanzania and Uganda. SIAT in Ghana and Ivory Coast
January 2021: Direct contact with FMO and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and members of parliament in the Netherlands after the launch of the Milieudefensie report using SOMO research. Contact and campaigns in several EU countries on the development banks (Germany, Belgium, UK, France) resulting in parliamentary questions and media attention.
(7) With the financial and technical support from SOMO, one of SOMO's partner organisations implemented the following interrelated activities, strengthening the capacities of 7 communities impacted by Kakuzi to engage in complaint and advocacy activities in an effort to realize remedy for the harms they have suffered: 1. Community capacity building to stand up for their rights, including organize community meetings and facilitate steering committee meetings. 2. Support court cases related to Kakuzi, including tracking progress on ongoing cases and updating communities on the progress made and ensure community participation. 3. Documenting emerging violations by the company affecting communities and workers, including collecting testimonies from communities and give input to a long read that will be published by SOMO. 4. Advocacy to gain support including scaling up contacts with the National Land Commission and members of Parliament/ County Assembly in order to raise support for affected communities.
(2) Kenyan tea workers have increased capacity to access remedy. In July 2020, a group of 218 current and former Kenyan tea workers have filed a formal complaint against Unilever for its failure to respect international human rights standards following widespread violence at the multinational’s largest tea plantation. Following coalition building among CSOs, the complaint was submitted to the United Nations Working Group on Business and Human Rights and the UN Special Rapporteur on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights by SOMO, a number of other CSOs and Leigh Day, who represents the 218 victims and has filed the complaint on their behalf. SOMO contributed to the complaint through research and input to the writing of the complaint, in particular analysis of the UNGPs
(5) Over the course of 2020, OECD Watch supported 5 LLMIC groups to file complaints to OECD National Contact Points with technical expertise on filing complaints. Support on other complaints filed by non-LLMIC-based organisations targeted impacts to groups in Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, India, China (Uighurs), and indigenous groups in the US and Norway.

(4)In 2019, more than 20 partners and CSOs in SOMO's network worldwide had better access to relevant and understandable data, tools and analysis on corporate research, allowing them to more effectively further their work and reach their goal by providing research support, strategic information and analysis. These partner organizations and CSOs benefited from increased and enhanced understanding on use of the current databases to strengthen their own understanding of companies and how they operate, as well as their corporate and capital structures as well as their financing. The CSO's and partners are better equipped to confront companies, their policies, their behaviour, their executives, and their financiers directly, or through shareholders, the press or legal or non-judicial means when they have better and more complete understanding of the companies. As a result, the following CSOs conduct their own research and lobby and advocacy: (1) Project Expedite Justice (Sudan) Project Expedite Justice requested data, analysis and research support in a case focused on a bank operating in Sudan, with financial flows between Switzerland and the Sudan Central Bank. The research is part of a body of work used in a case against a French bank accused of knowingly aiding genocide atrocities by evading economic sanctions. (1) GLAN (Western Sahara) requested data, investor information and analysis on an energy company working in North African and the Middle East with a specific focus on territorial waters in the OPT. The research supported follow up on financial connections for an OECD complaint. (1) Oxfam Thailand used data to confirm the legal connection between Tesco and Tesco Lotus with a focus on prominent Thai family shareholders. (1) PAX (Colombia) used data, analysis and support on a project focused identifying the financiers, including banks, of a company mining cobalt in Colombia. (3)A Korean NGO and 3 partners in Indonesia successfully filed three strategic complaints following OECD Watch's technical input on arguing the applicability of the OECD Guidelines to state-backed financial entities such as export-import banks. OECD Watch is hosted by SOMO. (1)Labcidade and SOMO are conducting a research together on public-private partnerships in downtown São Paulo and housing rights violations promoted by the state and corporations. The aim is to find out how these partnerships are closely connected to places where human rights violations occur. Primary research results have already been presented at a conference in Argentina, where academics, policy makers and activists were present. Eventually the findings will also be used to lobby the Brazilian regional government. (2)On June 25, 2019 13 CSO's (including Afrewatch and PremiCongo (DRC)) joined a Minerals Strategy Meeting in London organized by SOMO in collaboration with GoodElectronics and RAID. Organisations increased their knowledge on the growth in demand for minerals linked to the global transition to renewable energies, including in the transport sector, and the associated growth in demand for re-chargeable batteries. This growth is likely to have a huge impact on the global mining industry, and by extension workers, communities and the environment. As a result of this meeting, a new online platform (Mining and Energy Transition Forum) has been created for organizations to share their knowledge and strategies for L&A activities on the Just Transition and Mining. (1)The GoodElectronics network and SOMO organized the meeting of CIVIDEP and the Responsible Business Alliance (RBA), whereby the former advocated on the labor and human rights challenges that the electronics industry faces in the country. In preparation for this meeting CIVIDEP capacities were strengthened through the GoodElectronics Network by supporting research activities, such as publishing “Contemporary Reforms of Labour and Industrial Relations Laws: A situation analysis of the Indian Electronics Sector”, and campaigning to engage with workers. (2)In June 2019, 50 participants, including workers and CSOs (LIPS and FSPMI from Indonesia) attended a workshop organized by GoodElectronics on chemical exposure and biomonitoring in Batam, Indonesia. As a result of this workshop workers and organizations strengthened their capacity on this topics which allows them to advocate for better working conditions in the workplace. (2)SOMO helped prepare and accompanied a field visit by a leading British law firm to communities affected by sexual harassment and violence in Kenya. Kakuzi controls a lot of land in the area and their activities affect workers as well as communities that are situated in these areas. As preparation SOMO shared information about the case and the environment, establishing connection between the CBO Ndula Resource centre and the law firm. Ndula Resource centre prepared the field visit on site (invitees, meeting space etc). Kenya Human Rights Commission (KHRC) accompanied the visit and helped with trust building, translation etc. Bringing these parties together helps the CBOs in strengthening their case as well as their position in future lobby activities. Specific effort was made to involve female workers and communities in the site visit since they are most vulnerable to sexual harassment and violence. (5)SOMO’s plans to start with a research into business activities in occupied territories and do our first field work in Western Sahara in 2019, were complicated due to safety reasons in getting access to the Western Sahara. Therefore, mid 2019, SOMO connected to organizations in Europe working on the subject. After making the first contacts SOMO was invited to give a talk how to use corporate research in stopping transnational abuses in the Mediterranean Region at a conference in Barcelona. A group of research and campaigning NGOs (War on Want, Novact, SudsCat, Saharawi Campaign Against Plunder (SCAP) (1), AMRPEN (1), Western Sahara Resource Watch (1), Al Haq (1), Who Profits (1), Global Legal Action Network (GLAN), and SOMO) laid the foundation for further collaboration on the subject. As a first step in the process, the organizations will develop a scoping paper together to combine each other’s knowledge and experience for example for lobby and advocacy. (4)SOMO's partner organisations Kenya Human Rights Commission (KHRC) and CBO Ndula Research Center supported at least 4 communities in filing petitions in order to advocate for historical land rights. The communities were technically supported during the process of filing the petitions and are better able to voice their demands for remedy after learning from and engaging with the CBO. Following the petitions, the National Land Commission (NLC) of Kenya put out a formal notice in the legal Gazette which says that the agricultural company Kakuzi should give access to public utilities on its property and that its land leases should not be renewed. SOMO financially supported the communities to file petitions to the NLC. (5)Tailored support by GoodElectronics, hosted by SOMO, to be the coordinator (10 cases of tailor-made support) on request the members, e.g. support to the Maquiladora Health & Safety Support Network (1) to disseminate resource lists on key topics and aspects of workplace health and safety; support to ITUC’s (1) action on International Workers’ Memorial Day with the theme: Taking control - removing dangerous substances from the workplace; comments on an interview for a research on transnational labour governance; share contacts and disseminate invitation of CATAPA (1) for the Symposium: Challenging the ICT Supply Chain, from mining to procurement; comment LESN’s (1) report on batteries’ production in China; facilitating the sharing of the video documentary COMPLICIT to WAC (1) in the Philippines for a seminar on OHS; sharing and dissemination of different articles written by scholar Jenny Chan; and sharing of funding opportunities for GE members for instance partnerships offered by UNDP to CSOs. (6)Good Electronics, hosted by SOMO, contributed to various capacity building activities to organise and train workers, undertake negotiations, research, campaigning, etc. in order to and empower workers and communities, and address corporate abuse. Such as FARN (1) which carried out workshops and activities to strengthen indigenous communities affected by the extraction of lithium in the Olaroz-Cauchari basin and disseminate the results of the investigation Lithium extraction in Argentina. As part of the strategy to disseminate the results of the investigation, copies of the report were printed to be delivered to public officials and representatives of the affected communities. It was also disseminated by social networks and FARN website, as shown on FARN’s website. GoodElectronics, ICRT, LIPS, Solidar Suisse, AMRC and GET (5) organised an electronics strategy meeting bringing together 48 participants (20 women, 28 men) from 22 organisations. This strategy meeting focused on the electronics industry and the GoodElectronics Network itself. The main topics of discussion included: current landscape of the industry and mapping of the most pressing issues along the electronics supply chain; challenges foreseen by the member organisations for the next 3 years; evaluation of past work; future direction of the network; sustainability of the network; as well as the next steps for the network. (8)As part of the Good Electronics network and programme, hosted by SOMO, at least 8 organisations have strengthened their capacity to train workers to negotiate and demand their rights and to organize seminars on labour rights issues. For example, FSPMI managed that more than 13,000 members joined FSPMI SPEE (the electrical and electronics sector union) , which succeeded to finalize new collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) in 15 companies in addition to existing CBAs. Lomenik gained capacity to negotiate CBA and more than 2,000 members are newly covered by CBAs in 3 different companies. (6)PMA, MWAP, ALU, ILO-PHILS, and CFW (Philippines) (5): the unions have gained the capacity for organizing and union building throughout training sessions organized by IndustriALL (which is part of the GoodElectronics network, hosted by SOMO). The unions have updated and confirmed numerical organizing targets with identified companies and regions. As a result of the training sessions, the unions have agreed to have joint activity unity and set up organizing strategy such as to create common platform for lobby and advocacy for worker’s rights. VUIT (Vietnam) (1) has gained knowledge on CBA and OHS and its capacity for organizing and union building throughout the training sessions. The union has 160,000 members (including electronics workers) and continues to set the organizing targets and aim to gain 15,000 members by 2020 to improve their visibility and impact for lobby activities. VUIT will be planning to collaborate with VGCL to reach out to unorganized workers at new private MNCs established in the industrial zones.

*(2) 2 CSOs and 12 communities have increased knowledge on the impacts of uranium mining, the structure of the mining company and the mining company's responsibilities under the OECD guidelines for multinational enterprises as the result of 4 community workshops held in Tanzania in July 2018, and as such are better equipped to advocate for their rights. The CSOs, community members and (ex) mining workers reached with the workshop (total of 188 individuals) were unaware of some of the health and environmental risks related to uranium mining, the corporation behind the mine that is operating in their area, and the opportunities provided by the OECD guidelines to file complaints. This information really empowered the communities and ex workers to defend their rights, which was exemplified by an action undertaken by 32 ex mine workers right after the workshop to file a complaint with the District Director about the health impacts they suffer as a result of their past work for the mine. SOMO has funded and initiated the workshop, assisted the partners in organising the workshop, and played a central role in executing the workshop.
*(2) The advocacy capacity of 2 CSOs and members of a community that is impacted by an East-African agricultural company was strengthened in the sense that since July 2018, they have access to members of the United Nations Working Group on Business and Human Rights (UNWG), enabling them to communicate their grievances and advocate for their rights with an authoritative Human Rights body directly. The communities that are impacted by the East-African agricultural company have received little international attention for their struggles. The visit of the UNWG was a real boost to the profile of their grievances, and also brought more attention of the company to their situation: the UNWG confronted the company with the communities’ grievances at the same day in July 2018. The direct access to the UNWG is expected to be a significant advocacy entry for later advocacy. SOMO has been supporting the two CSOs on this case since 2016. In 2018 SOMO has informed the UNWG about the case, raised their interest in the case, and connected the UNWG with the two CSOs to organise for the community visits.
*(1) Together with 9 organizations, both from the global north and the global south, SOMO organized a Public Forum on Infrastructure in October 2018 in Indonesia. The forum was held parallel to the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank Group (WBG) which push infrastructure development. Case studies on reclamation, power plants, large scale tourism and infrastructure financing were presented by speakers from five countries in South and South East Asia . Issues of priority to women, indigenous peoples and local communities were specifically highlighted. The presentations touched on different aspects of infrastructure development, such as the main actors in planning, developing and financing of the projects, but also the impacts on land, water, environment, climate, people's lives and livelihood, etc. The above issues were addressed through presentations, case studies and small group discussions. It was a fruitful exchange and resulted in an article by Focus on the Global South in which they summarize the main dynamics of megaprojects as well as the impact on and struggles of communities affected. The need to understand the drivers behind, the dynamics of, and the impacts produced by megaprojects is increasingly urgent as infrastructure development is pushed by the G20 and IFI’s. SOMO’s contribution is capacity building on corporate and financial involvement and impacts of megaprojects in general. SOMO chaired the workshop, presented a case study and contributed financially so that communities affected by megaprojects could participate. Together with 9 other organizations we designed the program.
*(1) One CSO in Central Africa, with support from international CSOs, filed a complaint to the mechanism of the German Development Bank (DEG) in November regarding a palm oil plantation. SOMO provided advice to the CSOs involved in the complaint.
*(5) In 2018 at least 5 CSOs in LLMICs had better access to relevant data, tools and analysis on corporate research, allowing them to more effectively further their work and reach their goal by providing research support, strategic information and trainings. These partner organisations and CSOs benefited from increased and enhanced understanding on use of the current databases (Eikon, LexisNexis, Orbis and increasingly OpenSource tools) to strengthen their own understanding of companies and how they operate, as well as their corporate and capital structures. The data and analysis provided by the SOMO Corporate Research program helps CSOs and partners understand who a company’s equity shareholders and debt holders (including loans and bonds) are and therefore gives new strategic insight. The CSO’s and partners are better equipped to confront companies, their policies, their behavior, their executives, and their financiers directly, through shareholders, through the press or through legal or non-judicial means when they have better and more complete understanding of the companies.
*(5) GoodElectronics and SOMO supported and collaborated with a CSO from India to hold the national round-table on Working Conditions and Social Dialogue in the Indian Electronics Industry, in March 2018 in India, on the theme „Working Conditions and Social Dialogue in the Indian Electronics Industry‟. The round-table was attended by 350 participants including representatives of three Central trade unions another regional trade union. One highlight was the presence of global trade union IndustriALL. Also present were legal practitioners working on labour issues, academics, a government official responsible for occupational health and safety, 5 representatives from civil society and human rights organisations, and workers from the electronics sector. Based on this roundtable, (5) CSOs in India have been able to advocate on a wide array of topics including: i) labour issues (wages, working conditions, contract labour, social protection and the proposed labour reforms); ii) Occupational health and safety, exposure to chemicals and iii) Transparency in supply chains, policies and practices. During 2018, one of the CSOs advocated on the importance and need for accountability and transparency within global supply chains, key issues of concern for electronics workers across the world, as well as existing best policies and practices adopted by international organizations and networks. The CSO also had a bilateral call with the Responsible Business Alliance to bring up the issue of lack of participation by companies during social dialogue. RBA agreed to have a follow-up round-table in 2019. Ongoing campaigns, short-term and long-term objectives, strategies adopted, and ideas for solutions going forward, were also shared and discussed during the roundtable.
*(10) In September 2018, Good Electronics organized an electronics training and strategy meeting in the Philippines. More than 40 delegates from 24 organizations participated, including 12 organizations from LLMICs. All organizations strategized together and received training on labor rights, OHS, preventing and documenting chemical exposure. Building on this knowledge, at least (10) lobbied and advocated for better working conditions in their countries. For instance, two of them published a report on compressed workweek and discussed the impact of the policy in different fora at the end of 2018. Another CSO focused on intern labour in special economic zones while yet another aided union organizing. GoodElectronics and SOMO organized, facilitated and co-hosted the meeting. This meeting allowed participants to assess the current labour rights situation in major electronics production countries and provided a platform for exchange and strategizing together. Key issues presented by activists and labour advocates were discussed in order to align campaigning efforts across Asia. In particular, the issue of documenting cases of chemical exposure was discussed. Methods and Strategies used by Labor Groups and Organizations in the Regions were also jointly discussed. The meeting allowed defining clear action points such as, identify clear ways forward, appropriate actions and establish time frames, planning of Biomonitoring Project Implementation, identify the need to Improve Sharing and Communication with each other. The meeting focused on building the capacity on how to prove a case of occupational chemical exposure and participants received first-hand knowledge and tips from experts such as doctors, lawyers and union organizers. SOMO and GoodElectronics coordinated and supported the development of joint resources for research and advocacy. SOMO and GoodElectronics focused primarily on guiding the chemical safety and transparency discussion and the capacity building centering on workers’ right to know.
*(2) A Myanmar labour rights organisation and a trade union federation stepped up their supply chain research, having been familiarised with the concept of supply chain responsibility through SOMO trainings and discussions. Both had ample experience in pushing factories to improve labour conditions but did not yet have much experience in directly targeting the buyers of these factories. SOMO hosted a number of trainings focused on supply chain research, supply chain responsibility, and international corporate accountability norms. These kick started the two organisations into pressing European garment companies, business initiatives and multistakeholder initiatives to engage with Myanmar civil society stakeholders and to step up their efforts to address labour rights and human rights issues in the Myanmar garment industry. In February 2018, SOMO invited both organisations to Europe. SOMO organised a series of sessions, which were attended by representatives of companies, trade unions, civil society, government, MSIs and students. In addition, a number of bilateral meetings were held with companies (Jack Wolfskin, Otto), multistakeholder initiatives (FWF), NGOs (Mama Cash, CCC, Femnet) and journalists (Oneworld, NRC). During these sessions and meetings the organisations and SOMO provided information about human rights and labour rights risks and actual violations in the Myanmar garment industry. They urged corporate actors to engage with local civil society stakeholders stressed the importance of creating an enabling environment for unionization. In order to influence corporate and government behavior, access for local civil society stakeholders to public and private sector decision makers is vital. By conducting trainings, SOMO contributed to both organisations' capacity to dive into supply chain work. By organising the speaker tour SOMO facilitated engagement between the organisations and a number of European brands, government representatives, multi stakeholder initiatives and NGOs. SOMO, and the two organisations jointly prepared the meetings and during the course of the week the strategy was adapted where needed. The trade union federation is a women-led trade union. During the speaker tour there was particular attention for gender issues in the Myanmar garment industry
*(7) Throughout 2018, 7 LLMIC NGOs or workers groups in South East Asia, Central Africa, West Africa and MENA filed complaints to National Contact Points of the OECD Grievance Mechanism. The OECD Watch gave varying support and advice to complainants at different stages of their complaint-filing processes, from guidance on where and how to file, to guidance on how to draft their complaints. The capacity of these groups to use the OECD complaint system as well as the chance that they may receive some positive remedy for the harms they have incurred from irresponsible business conduct was increased OECD Watch learned how to support most effectively LLMIC communities in filing complaints; OECD Watch particularly learned how to handle complaints of threats to human rights defenders associated with complaints. LLMIC NGOs gained greater understanding on how to file effective complaints to National Contact Points.

31 CSOs in LLMICs increased skills, knowledge or network contacts to lobby and advocate for responsible corporate conduct. Through intensive research collaboration with SOMO the following CSOs have increased research skills and knowledge: 1) a CSO in occupied Palestinian Territories increased research skills and knowledge on the role of the private sector in gas exploration; 2) a CSO in Malawi increased research skills on land grabbing; 3) 2 CSOs in Myanmar increased research skills and knowledge on working conditions in the garment industry; 4) 2 Egyptian CSOs increased research skills and knowledge on ethics, human rights standards and clinical trials in Egypt by foreign pharmaceutical multinationals. 5) A CSO in India has increased knowledge and network contacts through attendance of 2nd IGWG session of the UN treaty on business and human rights in Geneva (made possible with support from SOMO). 6) Through membership in the OECD Watch Network (supported by SOMO), 41 CSOs from LLMICs (out of 129 members in total) increased their network contacts, and general on OECD Guidelines complaint or engaging in a complaint process. 3 CSOs from India, Kenya and Liberia served on the Coordination Committee. 5 CSO groups in LLMICs (DRC, Kenya, Nigeria, Cameroon, Bangladesh) and 4 in other countries (Thailand, Malaysia, Brazil, Colombia) have become strengthened through direct support in preparing a complaint and participating in the complaint process. 7) Through membership of the Good Electronics Network (supported by SOMO) 17 CSOs from LLMICs (out of 90 members in total) increased their network contacts. On 16-17 September 2016, a National Workshop on Contractualization in Quezon City, Philippines was held with the support of GoodElectronics. Participants agreed on a Declaration affirming their commitment towards achieving a pro-filipino industrialization strategy. 8) 25 CSOs in Nepal increased their skills on the UNGP through a training conducted by a Danish NGO with the use of SOMOs UNGP Guide for CSOs. 9) 4 CSOs from LLMICs and 5 from other countries have become aware of how non-judicial grievance mechanisms can be used to address corporate misconduct during 2 pilot e-learning presentations. SOMO provided them with information on different remedy options.

In 2017, 26 CSOs and civil society actors have lobbied and advocated for responsible corporate conduct based on increased skills, knowledge or network contacts. These actions of lobby and advocacy focused on capacity building activities in LLMIC countries. (1) In March 2021, four political parties submitted a bill on Responsible and Sustainable International Business Conduct in Dutch parliament. The bill proposes a duty of care for all companies in the Netherlands and an obligation to conduct due diligence in accordance with the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises for all enterprises with more than 250 employees.
The legislative proposal of the four parties (ChristenUnie, GroenLinks, PvdA, SP) imposes a duty of care on all companies in the Netherlands to address human rights violations and environmental damage in their value chains. Companies with more than 250 employees will be obliged to implement the six steps of due diligence, in line with the OECD Guidelines. The law will be enforced by a public regulator, which can issue financial sanctions. Repeated failure within five years to stop activities that cause or contribute to negative impacts or to provide remedy will be considered a criminal offence, punishable by fines and jail. The bill also enables third parties to hold companies liable in civil court for harms suffered as a result of a violation of the law. If adopted, the law would replace the Child Labour Due Diligence Law, which was passed by the Senate in 2019. SOMO has contributed to the political debate around responsible business conduct for years with various research reports and has contributed to L&A through MVO platform (hosted by SOMO) as well.
(1) In March 2021, the European Parliament adopted with a large majority, the Parliament’s Legal Affairs Committee (JURI) legislative own-initiative report by MEP Lara Wolters (S&D/PvdA) on corporate due diligence and corporate accountability with recommendations for the European Commission on necessary next steps to be taken. The report can be seen as a strong recommendation from the Parliament to the European Commission to develop an ambitious EU Directive. The European Commission has announced it will publish its proposal for a directive in June. With this report, the European Parliament has shown its strong support for the ongoing legislative initiative on sustainable corporate governance launched in 2020 by the European Commission. This proposal, which is expected to be tabled in June 2021, aims to require businesses to conduct due diligence in order to prevent and address human rights and environmental risks and impacts within their own operations and value chains; as well as provide access to judicial remedy when harm occurs. SOMO and ECCJ have been advocating for EU commitment to a legally binding instrument for companies.or years. SOMO has supported the ECCJ through financial support, advice and participation in the steering group.

Dialogue occurred and resulted in ANZ Bank committing to 1) review and strengthen its human rights policies, including its customer social and environmental screening processes, 2) ensure a specific grievance mechanism accessible to affected communities, and 3) provide monetary compensation to victims. *(1) Electronics Watch brings together public sector buyers and CSOs to monitor working condition in electronics factories. They do so through worker-driven monitoring.
