*(1) In September 2018, the UN Special Rapporteur on toxics submitted 1 report to the UNHRC, stressing that exposure of workers to toxic chemicals is a form of exploitation. He urged governments to criminalize workers exposure and to guarantee that victims do not bear the burden of proof. He also offered 15 principles on duties and responsibilities to prevent exposure, including workers’ right to know applicability of criminal liability. Tens of millions of workers are exposed to hazardous substances in the workplace every day. The electronics industry is no exception as it uses toxic substances throughout its lifecycle. Cases from around the world have brought to light the extent to which electronics workers are exposed to toxic chemicals at work. These cases have implicated governments and companies in the world’s richest and poorest countries along the lifecycle of electronic goods – from the extraction of raw materials to the manufacture of electronic components and products, to recycling and recovery operations. SOMO and GoodElectronics were key contributors and advocates for the development of these principles, by contributing during an expert consultation held by the Rapporteur on May 2018 in Geneva prior to drafting the principles. SOMO and GoodElectronics also co-authored the report Exploitation by Deception with Baskut Tuncak and co-organized a panel discussion during the UN Forum Business and human Rights in November. SOMO contributed with recommendations and feedback during the expert meeting on the protection of workers from toxic chemicals that took place in Geneva between 16 and 17 May organized by the Special Rapporteur on Toxic Chemicals. SOMO/GoodElectronics also co-authored the report “Exploitation by deception in the electronics industry” which argues that, when workers are not provided with relevant information about the toxic and otherwise hazardous substances in the workplace they are actually or potentially being exposed to, this could constitute exploitation by deception.

# mechanisms, policies and regulations improved by national, regional and international government bodies to ensure companies promote more sustainable practices and are held accountable for respecting human rights and the environment and providing adequate remedy to victims of adverse impacts

comment.narrative:
(1) In a letter to parliament and a policy document of October 2020, the Dutch government has made explicit it sees human rights due diligence (HRDD) legislation as core element of its CSR policy.
MVO Platform has advocated for due diligence for years and has at least in part contributed to the parliament’s view on HRDD legislation. SOMO has supported the MVO Platform through financial support, advice and participation in its steering group to advocate for due diligence legislation.

(1)Over the years, many researches of SOMO have shed light on the problem of child labour. Now the Dutch original legislative proposal stated in its introduction that a child labour law is needed because child labour is still widespread in many parts of the world, and Dutch markets are part of the supply chains. To substantiate this, reference is made a.o. to three SOMO reports (on mica, shoes, and garments) which were co-produced with partner organisations in LLMIC. In May 2019, the Dutch Senate voted to adopt the Child Labor Due Diligence Law. When the law enters into force, all companies selling products on the Dutch market will be required to show that they are addressing the issue of child labour in their global supply chains. This law is an important step towards the adoption of mandatory due diligence legislation in the Netherlands and Europe, which is necessary in addressing business-related human rights and environmental impacts. Former member of Parliament Roelof van Laar, who drew up the draft bill, stated that news about exploitation of children as brought by SOMO in the report Flawed Fabrics have led him to come up with the draft bill.
(1)Following OECD Watch's first-ever complaint against an NCP to the OECD Investment Committee, in July 2019 the Australian Treasury Department selected its first Independent Examiner, thereby launching a new organisational structure for the NCP to improve the independence, accountability, and legitimacy of the grievance mechanism. This outcome is significant because it represents a concrete improvement in a government complaints-handling body. The Australian NCP is now more independent from government and business interest, and thereby more legitimate and accountable to complaints, including CSOs from LLMICs seeking remedy for abuse by Australian corporations. SOMO, as secretariat of OECD Watch, coordinated with the network and specifically Australian members to develop and file the complaint and also encourage the Australian NCP to reform its overall procedures and organisational structure. (1)Through supporting civil society complainants from the Netherlands and Turkey, OECD Watch contributed to the Dutch National Contact Point deciding that the right to culture and cultural heritage is covered by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, and thus expected to be respected by covered MNEs. Recognition of this responsibility has the potential to improve conduct of corporations and also expand grounds by which CSOs, including from LLMICs, can seek remedy via NCPs for impacts they have suffered to their cultural heritage. SOMO supported this outcome by hosting the OECD Watch network. (1)Through supporting complainants from the Netherlands, OECD Watch contributed to the Dutch NCP deciding that the OECD Guidelines expect financial institutions to fulfill their climate-related commitments. This outcome is significant because it represents the first time an NCP has clearly asserted that climate issues and related responsibility of corporations are covered by the OECD Guidelines. This paves the way for other NGOs to seek accountability from financial institutions or other enterprises for failure to comply with their own climate commitments, and encourages other NCPs similarly to interpret climate change as covered by the OECD Guidelines. SOMO supported this outcome by hosting the OECD Watch secretariat. (1)Through co-chairing the OECD financial sector due diligence advisory group, OECD Watch raised perspectives of and facilitated access by CSOs and communities from LLMIC and non-LLMIC organisations in several direct consultations to secure the adoption of several tangible improvements into the text of the new due diligence guidance, particularly clarifying when financial institutions can contribute to their clients' impacts. Other stakeholders were OECD governments, Business at OECD, and major financial institutions. In response to recommendations in SOMO’s publication 'Overpriced, drugs developed with Dutch public funding' 2 governmental bodies have improved their policies. (2)The National Health Care Institute (Zorginstituut Nederland) - one of the most prominent governmental institutes for health - decided to develop a framework for attaching conditionalities to licenses for their new subsidy scheme for 2020 for 70 million Euro. A delegation of The National Health Care Institute approached SOMO and Wemos for advice and exploring possibilities after thorough reading of the report.ZonMw, another Dutch Institute with subsidy schemes for health related research, is also exploring how to apply conditionalities with the 'Ten Principles for Socially Responsible Licensing' (June 2019) developed by the NFU (The Netherlands Federation of University Medical Centres). SOMO provided input for the formulation of the ten principles. Based on these examples it can be concluded that in the Netherlands policy changes have taken place at governmental bodies regarding the attachment of conditionalities to the public funding of biomedical R&D.

*(1) In May 2018, the OECD Council of Ministers unanimously adopted 1 new normative standard for responsible business conduct, in the form of the OECD Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Business Conduct. The Guidance was accompanied by an OECD Council Recommendation, which is the highest form of political endorsement at the OECD, giving it the same status as an international treaty. CSOs in LLMICs will now be able to call upon OECD and adhering governments to ensure that their companies operating in LLMICs implement this stringent new standard for due diligence to avoid, mitigate and remedy adverse impacts. As the guidance was being developed between June 2016 and May 2018, SOMO, as secretariat of the OECD Watch network, was the lead negotiator in developing the guidance on behalf of civil society. SOMO coordinated civil society input and conducted advocacy with governments.
*(1) SOMO, through the OECD Watch network (hosted by SOMO), intensively advocated for reform of the peer review process by the OECD through a preliminary report in November 2017, a full report in June 2018, and a submission to the OECD in October 2018. In response to SOMO's advocacy, the OECD committed to reform its peer review process and submitted a draft proposal (non-public document) outlining proposed new procedures that draw from 5 of the recommendations OECD Watch had made in its submissions. This outcome is significant because it will strengthen the process by which NCPs review each other, yielding greater transparency in the review process, greater protections for NGOs to raise comments and concerns during the review, and greater accountability from NCPs in implementing recommended reforms of their practices and procedures for complaint handling.
*(1) On 2 July 2018, minister Kaag again confirmed the government’s target set out in policy document MVO Loont (2013): 90% of big companies (with more than 500 employees, total assets of more than 20 million euro and a net turnover of more than 40 million euro) in the Netherlands have to commit to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. Working towards this target, the trade agenda (Handelsagenda) with the note “Investeren in perspectief”, that was published on 5 October 2018, now includes a budget indicator (begrotingsindicator), which can be seen as a direct policy change. The target mentioned above has to be reached in 2023 and in 2018 and 2020 intermediary assessments will take place. Commitment to the OECD Guidelines also remains a condition for company participation in trade missions and government support from the ‘BZ-handelsinstrumentarium’. Although it is not yet clear what “commitment” means, Minister Kaag stated that companies should not only commit to the OECD Guidelines, but specifically ‘comply’. The MVO Platform has been advocating for increased commitment to the OECD Guidelines as well as improvement of ‘BZ-handelsinstrumentarium’ for years. That company commitment will now also be monitored with a specific budget indicator that indicates the importance of the Dutch government attaching to this goal. In general, this government does not impose any normative policies on companies, but this is a clear exception. It is expected that increased conscious commitment to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises will lead to increased responsible business conduct and corporate human rights abuses. Through participation in the steering group and meetings of the MVO Platform, SOMO contributes to coordinated policy advocacy by 29 Dutch CSOs to introduce or strengthen corporate accountability related policy processes at the national (Dutch) level. As host of OECD Watch SOMO has particular knowledge about the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises that it can contribute to related lobby and advocacy. Measuring the commitment of large Dutch companies to comply to the OECD Guidelines is expected to create some level of pressure on companies that conduct due diligence in order to prevent and mitigate negative impacts in their operations and supply chains, including those in LLMICs. Moreover, this budget indicator (begrotingsindicator) also provides input to the development of new policy instruments in the Netherlands, which may further improve responsible business conduct of companies in LLMICs. The direct role of civil society in this outcome is limited however, the active promotion, public endorsement and the measurement of companies’ compliance to OECD Guidelines by the Dutch Government increases the potential leverage civil society in LLMICs has on Dutch companies operating in their countries, especially those corporations that receive financial or (non) financial support as part of the Private Sector Development instruments of the Dutch government.
*(1) End of November 2018 the Dutch government published the new criteria for the transparency benchmark, which monitors the qualitative and quantitative development of sustainability reporting of the biggest Dutch companies. Among other things, these new criteria include an indicator that measures whether a company commits to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and about which of the six steps of conducting (human rights) due diligence as outlined in the OECD’s Due Diligence Guidance it reports. The MVO Platform has been advocating for increased commitment to the OECD Guidelines for years. The new criteria reflect the importance that the Dutch government attaches to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and conducting (human rights) due diligence. Also, more specific and comprehensive sustainability reporting can give concrete information for further lobby and advocacy. It is further expected that increased conscious commitment to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises will lead to increased responsible business conduct, and less corporate human rights abuses suffered by workers and communities in LLMICs. Through participation in the steering group and meetings of the MVO Platform, SOMO contributes to coordinated policy advocacy by 29 Dutch CSOs to introduce or strengthen corporate accountability related policy processes at the Dutch level. As host of OECD Watch SOMO has particular knowledge about the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises that it can contribute to related lobby and advocacy. The government expects that measuring and publishing statistics on the reporting of large Dutch companies on their implementation of the six steps of due diligence as described in the OECD Due Diligence Guidance has a positive effect on responsible business conduct by companies. Sound implementation of due diligence process should lead to the prevention and mitigation of negative impacts in the operations and supply chains of these companies, including those that take place in LLMICs. Moreover, this indicator also provides input to the development of new policy instruments in the Netherlands, which may further improve responsible business conduct of companies in LLMICs. The direct role of civil society in this outcome is limited however, the active promotion, public endorsement the measurement of companies’compliance to the OECD Due Diligence Guidance by Dutch Government increases the potential leverage civil society in LLMICs has on Dutch companies operating in their countries, especially those corporations that receive financial or (non) financial support as part of the Private Sector Development instruments of the Dutch government.
*(1) In 2018, the EU Directive 2014/95/EU that requires mandatory non-financial reporting by over 8000 EU companies became effective for all years beginning on or after January 1, 2017. Companies subject to the directive should include non-financial reports either within their management report or as a separate document. The directive includes guidelines that stipulate that companies are required to report on the human rights, environmental and social impacts of their global operations, as well as their policies and due diligence procedures for identifying, preventing, mitigating and addressing those impacts. Companies will have to disclose information in relation to their own operations and business relationships. This is a new practice coming into force after the European Coaliation for Corporate Justice (ECCJ) had been intensely advocating for this Directive since 2012. ECCJ had teamed up with other CSOs including the European trade union confederation (ETUC). Between 2012 and 2014, ECCJ led an advocacy campaign aimed at EU decision makers in the Parliament, the Commission and the Council, while mobilising ECCJ's member organisations at national level and doing continuous media work. ECCJ also provided its member organisations with briefings and advice for the transposition period between 2014-2016 when the Directive had to be transposed into national law, so that the members were able to advocate for the important points to be established in national law. Conducting non-financial reporting helps investors, consumers, policy makers and other stakeholders to evaluate the non-financial performance of large companies and encourages these companies to develop a responsible approach to business. Better, more specific and comprehensive sustainability reporting can give concrete information for further lobby and advocacy. It is further expected that increased conscious commitment to non-financial reporting will lead to increased responsible business conduct, and less corporate human rights abuses suffered by workers and communities in LLMICs. Through financial support and participation in the steering group and meetings of ECCJ, SOMO and FGG contribute to coordinated policy advocacy by the European network to introduce or strengthen corporate accountability related policy processes at the European level.

11 mechanisms, policies and regulations were improved or introduced by national, regional and international government bodies to ensure companies promote more sustainable practices and are held accountable for respecting human rights and the environment and providing adequate remedy to victims of adverse impacts. These include: 1) inclusion in the Dutch Sustainable Garment and Textile Sector Agreement concluded by the Dutch government of due diligence requirements for corporate signatories, including requirement to conduct a thorough and phased due diligence proccess and publicly disclose results on an aggregate level. SOMO participated in the initial stage of negotiation and advocated for the due diligence requirements ; 2) The Hanze University of Applied Sciences committed to fair procurement conditions by becoming an affiliate to Electronics Watch (EW) and thereby incorporating the Electronics Watch contract conditions in contracts for the supply of electronics goods. These conditions include human rights and labour standards, worker-driven verification and enforcement. SOMO contributed to the result by participating in the EW of Board of Trustees and collaborating with EW to recruit more Dutch affiliates. 3) The OECD made improvements to 4 general and sector-specific policy documents on responsible business: agriculture (in relation to Free, Prior and Informed Consent), financial sector (in relation to responsible disengagement), garments (in relation to child labour and employment discrimination, as well as measures to increase sectoral collaboration through the disclosure of information) and general due diligence. SOMO supports and hosts the OECD Watch network, which actively participated in advisory group meetings and commented on drafts of all the sector policy documents (together called pro-active agenda). OECD Watch is the recognised NGO stakeholder for the Working Party on Responsible Business Conduct. 4) At a meeting in June 2016, the EU Foreign Affairs Council adopted conclusions on business and human rights that includes language calling for International Financial Institutions (IFIs) to ensure human rights compliance and that grievance mechanisms operate in line with the UN Guiding Principles. The conclusions also called for further enhancement of the effectiveness of National Contact Points (NCPs). SOMO advocated intensely for these measures, including as a co-host of the conference ‘EU Roadmap to Business and Human Rights’, hosted by the Dutch government, which preceded the meeting. 5) In June 2016, a proposal for conflict minerals legislation led to the decision within the European Commission on a new EU conflict minerals legislation, this process was influenced by SOMO and its partners through extensive lobby and advocacy in the past years. 6) Germany formally agrees to adjust their policies in order to restructure & improve NCP. In June 2016 the Danish NCP have changed case handling procedures as follow up to their peer review in 2015 that OECD Watch provided input into. SOMO supports and hosts the OECD Watch network.

Through corporate accountability, including transparency and safeguard policies, conflict resolution mechanisms and policies promoting social justice, decent work and sustainability together with local partners, in 2017 SOMO has facilitated and arranged meetings that have led to 5 policies that have been improved by governments in the North. More specifically, (1) the paper on Responsible Business Conduct for Institutional Investors explains the application of the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises in the context of institutional investors. This highlights key considerations for institutional investors in carrying out due diligence to identify and respond to environmental and social risks. By promoting responsible business conduct amongst Northern companies, those operating in LLMIC countries are likely to be more responsible and less likely to breach the Guidelines in their operations. Furthermore, (2,3) OECD Watch has been calling for mandatory peer reviews as they reveal valuable lessons for NCPs. Peer reviews can lead to recommendations to improve NCPs and thereby access to remedy for victims of human rights abuses. (4) A final mechanism promoting sustainable practices is the Covenant for Responsible Gold, which was signed by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs in June 2017. This result is based on the research of SOMO, published in April 2016. SOMO organized a meeting in 2016 before the launch of the report with stakeholders to discuss the outcomes of the research. Representatives from the electronics industry, civil society organisations, experts and policymakers have developed concrete next steps towards responsible sourcing of minerals. (5) The policy of an EU regulation is changed to ensure companies promote more sustainable practices and are held accountable for respecting human rights. The budgetary control committee of the European Parliament voted in favour of an amendment on the European Medicines Agency (EMA). This policy states that EMA must report its activities on protecting clinical trial participants and guaranteeing that trials are conducted according to ethical guidelines.

2016-2017: 19 mechanisms, policies and regulations improved or introduced by national, regional and international government bodies to ensure companies promote more sustainable practices and are held accountable for respecting human rights and the environment and providing adequate remedy to victims of adverse impacts.
2019: * In 2019 the Office of the High Commissioner on Human Rights’s guidance for States on non-state-based grievance mechanisms (1) –developed to inform state policy- is strengthened through SOMO’s input on best practices on Independent Accountability Mechanisms. * In 2019 the United Nations Working Group’s guidance on business and human rights and due diligence (1) -developed to inform state business policy- with relation to gender is strengthened through SOMO’s expertise. * In 2019 5 NCPs and the OECD (1) improve their policies related to handling complaints and guaranteeing access to remedy to victims in LLMICs as a result of OECD Watch advocacy that is financially supported by SOMO, which also hosts the network. * In 2019 1 legislation regarding non-financial reporting will be improved by the EU after the planned 2019 evaluation of current Non-Financial Reporting legislation to which the European Coalition for Corporate Justice will contribute by proposing improvements to the law based on qualitative evaluation of the current legislation with financial support from SOMO. * In 2019 awareness will be raised by SOMO and its lobby partner Wemos among the European regulator (EMA) that the provision of Post Trial Access to treatment (PTA) to trial participants in LLMICs should be safeguarded according to the current regulation on clinical trials, resulting in (at least) 1 improved policy.

(1) In 2020, one National Contact Point (NCP) or the OECD improve their policies related to handling complaints and guaranteeing access to remedy to victims in LLMICs as a result of OECD Watch advocacy that is financially supported by SOMO, which also hosts the network.
(1) In 2020 the European Commission will release an Action Plan on Responsible Business that includes steps and measures proposed by the European Coalition for Corporate Justice (ECCJ), financially supported by SOMO, to ensure that the EU complies with the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and thereby leads to a better track record of EU businesses in respecting rights of people and organizations in LLMICs.

comment.narrative: (1)SOMO and partner organisations in Myanmar researched human rights and labour rights issues in Myanmar. During the research process and after publication, SOMO engaged in a lobby strategy towards the AGT secretariat to persuade them to do more to raise awareness among their members about the human rights and labour rights risks in Myanmar and the need to develop and implement rigorous country-specific due diligence procedures. In 2019 AGT informed SOMO that they revised their performance review format which now contains the topic of human rights and labour rights risks in the Myanmar garment industry. AGT had taken several actions to persuade AGT members to develop and implement rigorous country-specific human rights due diligence (HRDD) procedures. Such as sharing publications (also from SOMO) and addressing risk policies in individual performance review meetings with companies. (1)Through supporting civil society complainants from Switzerland, OECD Watch helped secure an agreement via the Swiss National Contact Point between the NGO and Credit Suisse. Credit Suisse agreed to require its clients to incorporate language into its internal guidelines on project financing for the oil & gas, mining, and forestry & agribusiness sectors. In this way, clients will demonstrate alignment with International Finance Corporation Performance Standard 7 - Indigenous Peoples, which incorporates the principles of free prior and informed consent (FPIC). This agreement is significant because it means every project finance client of the IFC should ensure FPIC in order to receive CS' investment, and because this may encourage other major banks to follow suit setting FPIC requirements for their clients. (18)More than 13,000 members newly joined FSPMI SPEE (the electrical and electronics sector union) and the union succeeded to finalize new collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) in 15 companies in addition to existing CBAs. Trade union Lomenik gained capacity to negotiate CBA and more than 2,000 members are newly covered by CBAs in 3 different companies. The union continues to target companies located in industrial zone, for expanding organizing drive. The union also set up targets for CBA negotiations in certain companies. CBAs generally aim for improved working conditions that are formally recognized and that workers can refer to when claiming their rights.

*(1) Apple improved their Supplier Responsibility 2018-Progress Report student intern policy to limit the number of student interns at its suppliers facilities to 10% of their total workforce. Student interns are being abused by suppliers to meet peak orders, while they conduct normal working tasks they are not paid the same and their job doesn't provide any educational development. Since 2012, through research and advocacy SOMO & GoodElectronics supported two partners in their campaigns evidencing poor working conditions at Apple suppliers. Since 2012, through research and advocacy SOMO & GoodElectronics supported partners in their campaigns evidencing poor working conditions at Apple suppliers, most notably the “iSlave at 10 Campaign” which highlighted a corrupt trade union election at Apple’s suppliers, student intern abuses and extremely low wages. As a result of this campaigns Apple acknowledged cases of students working overtime and started a formal investigation. “The driving force from Apple (and other brands) for quick production when new models are to be launched is very strong, so much so that suppliers like Foxconn and Quanta have to rely on flexible employment to meet the delivery requirements. It concerns Roche (Switzerland) and Novartis (Switzerland), both these companies were subject of research for the publication ‘Industry-sponsored clinical drug trials in Egypt’ conducted by SOMO, Wemos, Public Eye and two Egyptian organisations in 2016. When people participating in clinical trials lose access to promising experimental treatments or comparable therapies, they may experience devastating health effects, especially for chronic diseases, e.g., cancer. For vulnerable populations in low- and middle-in-come countries, without the means to access alternative treatments, this loss may be especially difficult and could lead to relapse or other worsening conditions. 'Post-trial access' describes the continued provision of a product to clinical trial participants after a trial has concluded. Company policies on PTA are important to protect vulnerable clinical trial participants in LLMICs. The lack of post-trial access to treatment (PTA) was one of the findings of the research. In follow-up on this publication we went into dialogue with Novartis. Whereas Roche decided to try a judicial process to have the report adapted which did not succeed and only led to more attention to their case in 2017. Also as a result of the publication (on Egypt) and the earlier publication of SOMO on PTA ‘Post-trial access to treatment, Corporate best practices’, the Access to Medicines Index included in the Methodology for 2018 an indicator for post-trial access to treatment. This was a good outcome in 2017, because this forces the top 20 pharmaceutical companies to report about their post-trial access policies. SOMO provided input for this indicator. In the 2018 Access to Medicines Index (November 2018) the policies of the top 20 pharmaceutical companies on post-trial access to medicines are evaluated and the outcome is that only three companies – GSK, Novartis and Roche – meet all criteria looked for by the Index. Remarkably, it is Novartis and Roche who has published new policies on PTA in 2018 and they are well rewarded for it by the Index. The ATM-index says about Novartis ‘The best policy is from Novartis’ and about Roche: ‘Roche rises 5 (to 14th), with a new, clear policy on providing clinical trial participants with post-trial access to candidate medication’. Another conclusion of the index is that 14 companies have polices in place on PTA However, they vary in their level of rigour: few are publicly available, and few are supported by a concrete example of where post-trial access has been provided in a country in scope. This is more or less in line with the findings of SOMO’s research on PTA.
